thread.title: Boulder suspends panhandling enforcement as City Council weighs revisions
thread.title_full: Boulder suspends panhandling enforcement as City Council weighs revisions - The Denver Post

author: Sarah Kuta
title: Boulder suspends panhandling enforcement as City Council weighs revisions
text:
As a result of a federal court ruling that found parts of a Grand Junction panhandling ordinance unconstitutional, police will stop enforcing a similar law in Boulder and the City Council on Tuesday night will consider an emergency ordinance to address the issue.
The ruling, which came last week, found that parts of a Grand Junction law restricting panhandling violated the First Amendment's protection of free speech.
City attorney Tom Carr is recommending the changes to Boulder's ordinances, which currently restrict panhandling on the Pearl Street Mall and the University Hill business district.
The city is also considering repealing the law that prohibits aggressive begging. Instead, Carr recommends changing the language to prohibit begging that is "intimidating, threatening, coercive or obscene and that causes the person solicited to reasonably fear for his or her safety," according to a news release.
The council will consider Carr's recommendations at its regularly scheduled meeting at 6 p.m. Tuesday in council chambers at the Municipal Building, 1777 Broadway.
In the spring of 2014, the council briefly considered an ordinance that would have prohibited panhandling at places where people might feel trapped or already have their wallets out, such as outdoor dining areas, playgrounds, ATMs, bus stops and gas pumps. A vote on the proposed ordinance was cancelled because of concerns and questions from councilmembers.
